Congress must develop new tools to promote competition in these markets and across the board, prohibit price gouging, and address the profiteering that has led to an outbreak of inflation so that America's supply chains remain resilient and secure for many years to come.

The U.S. needs a fairer, more competitive, stronger food system. That is why @POTUS announced a four-part plan to bring down costs and create a more resilient meat and poultry supply chain.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2022/01/03/white-house-beef-supply/

We live in a country where large corporations have boxed out independent businesses that are lifelines to our local communities and critical sources of competition to these dominant firms.
https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/15/opinion/meat-meatpacking-industry.html
And when a single facility controls a large portion of production, one problem with that one factory’s production process can have ripple effects throughout the country.
Immense levels of economic concentration increase the likelihood of price-fixing, collusion, and other criminally illegal antitrust violations.

Consolidation at the grocery retail level is just as harmful. Independent grocers cannot compete with mega-corporations that have greater buying power. Consumers do not always know the full extent of grocer consolidation due to the big chains’ branding practices. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FJeWUELXIAUp1ll.jpg

Nearly every link of America's food supply chain is dominated by a handful of corporations. For example, four companies produce over 80% of our nation’s beef market. So it’s painful, and long, and you have to exhaust Republican speakers and table or stop dilatory motions and amendments, but you can get to a simple majority vote — eventually.
There can be a vote to overrule the call, which is debatable; but when that fails, whatever motion or amendment was ruled dilatory ends.

“Dilatory” motions, amendments and other delaying mischief can be ruled out of order by the presiding officer.  It takes a fair amount of nonsense before it becomes clearly dilatory, but it’s then a simple point of order—no vote.
The motion to table allows the Senate to clear the decks of amendments. Each requires a vote, but is not debatable. Week after week, even through weekends, table the bad amendments.

Another is the Senate speak-twice rule. Senators who’ve spoken twice on a question can be ruled out of order if they keep at it. That’s why real filibusters were long, uninterrupted speeches. Not one and done, but two and done.  (Yup, that’s 100 speeches by Rs — sorry!)

One is my DISCLOSE Act being in the bill.  Republicans must vote against it for their dark-money donors, but that kills them with voters. Ditto gerrymandering. Lots of focus on those painful votes for them in the bill will help.

Black history is American history, and today we honored an American hero. 

Congratulations, Willie O’Ree! Today, we give you your flowers. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FJgazYyWQAAvcpz.jpg

TY @QuigleyCampaign, @Higgins4WNY, @tomemmer, @RepJohnKatko for your partnership on this critical bill. 

And to the grassroots movement pushing for years to ensure Willie takes his rightful place in history—none of this would be possible without you. Thank you.

Willie’s story reminds us to not only take up space, but to create it—and pave the way for others to do the same. 

With this honor, he joins Jackie Robinson, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Coretta Scott King, the Tuskegee Airmen & more.🏅

Incredible company for an incredible man.

After retiring, Willie spent time paying it forward to the next generation.

He was @NHL's Director of Youth Development & Diversity Ambassador, and worked to increase opportunities for young Black and brown players & help them take their rightful place in the big league too.

Willie was a speedy left winger—but even he couldn't out-skate racism as the sole Black player in the NHL.

He faced fierce discrimination & even violence from fans & players alike.

Despite it all, Willie embodied resilience, grace, dignity & never gave up on his dream.

Willie O’Ree is a descendent of enslaved people who made history with the @NHLBruins 64 years ago when he became the first Black player to play in the @NHL.

He played 45 games in the NHL & spent over 20 years in pro hockey—all while hiding the fact that he was blind in one eye.

Willie O’Ree is a hockey legend, trailblazer, ice breaker, hero & activist whose powerful story is unknown to far too many. 

We changed that today when the House passed our Willie O’Ree Congressional Gold Medal Act—the highest honor Congress can give a civilian. 🧵 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FJgaBGCX0AMdP7f.jpg

Of course, one can support the Voting Rights Act, as I do, and as @SenatorCollins does and still believe the pre-clearance requirement is constitutionally impermissible. It is a case of apples and oranges.
As restoration of pre-clearance as advocated by @SenOssoff would not be done as an extraordinary remedy for current discrimination, it would clearly not be permitted by the federal courts.
Because the coverage in 2013 was based on decades-old data and eradicated practices, the Supreme Court struck it down.
As a rule, the Supreme Court noted: "The Federal Government does not ... have a general right to review and veto state enactments before they go into effect."
By 2009, however, as the Supreme Court noted in Shelby, “the racial gap in voter registration and turnout [was] lower in the States originally covered by §5 than it [was] nationwide.”

That provision, Section 5, was originally applied in 1965 to Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Virginia. The additional covered subdivisions included 39 counties in North Carolina and one in Arizona. Subsequently other jurisdictions were added.

What @SenOssoff is advocating is that states be required to ask PERMISSION of the Biden Department of Justice before they can make any changes in state voting laws.  A similar provision was struck down in 2013 by the United States Supreme Court in Shelby County vs. Holder.
In fact, that is the basis of the Department of Justice's  current lawsuit against the state of Georgia.

.@SenatorCollins is entirely correct in her debate with @SenOssoff about the Voting Rights Act.  Section 2, WHICH APPLIES NATIONWIDE,  prohibits the denial or abridgement of the right of any citizen to vote on account of race, color, or membership in a language minority group.
